Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2010 08:30PM dharmamama wrote: Please remember that statistics do not necessarily apply to you. With that in mind, I do hope that one of these treatments, or any number of possible "miracles" comes your way. the body is too complicated for anyone to fully understand, as is it's ability to heal. You are certainly in my thoughts and prayers.

I hope we can all stand before our Oncologists some day and be told that we too, have beat the odds!
Posts.Title: Will I Always be "In Treatment"? dharmamama Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2010 01:53PM dharmamama wrote: The older I get, the more I realize that I just don't know much at all. Just when I think "I know" I am healthy-I get cancer. Then when I think, "I can't possibly recover enough to go back to work", Whammo! I am back working full time. We all have a heck of a road ahead of us, no matter what our diagnosis is. We get to learn how to walk with no real ground under our feet. But, at least for today, I  am alive and grateful.

Posts.Title: Will I Always be "In Treatment"? dharmamama Lowrider54

Posts.Content: dharmamama wrote: I am fairly new to being classified as stage 4 and an eternal optimist..with that in mind, I have a question- will I always be receiving one form of chemo, immunotherapy, anti hormonal therapy for the rest of my life? I have friends that  are stage 4 long term survivors,one from prostate ca and the other bone ca. Both received additional radiation, surgery and chemo after their met diagnosis, and both have been NED for greater than 10 years. They never had long term treatment, but it seems like most stage 4 breast ca survivors remain on treatment even though they are NED.  A bit about me- I had stage 3 breast ca last year, and was diagnosed with a single brain met this year which was removed and the tumor bed zapped with cyberknife. I am currently on Herceptin and didn't tolerate Tykerb. I appreciate your feedback :)  Dx 6/7/2009, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 17/19 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Will I Always be "In Treatment"? dharmamama Lowrider54

Posts.Content: dharmamama wrote: I had a single brain met 5 years ago and had craniotomy and cyberknife rads. It came back in the same location a year later and I had another Craniotomy which removed more of the tumor bed and had a higher dose of Cyberknife rads. I have been on Herceptin for over 6 years and have SE's (nausea, dizziness, low counts)which is rare. I couldn't tolerate Tykerb. Being that Herceptin cannot cross the Blood Brain Barrier, every Dr I have seen has just told me that they don't really know if Herceptin can do anything, but have allowed me to stay on treatment as a preventative for any systemic disease that may or may not occur. Anyone else on Herceptin only? I am now 4 years NED, but am getting tired of feeling crappy. Dx 6/7/2009, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 17/19 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: dharmamama wrote: I had a unilateral mastectomy 2 years ago without reconstruction and now that life has settled I am going to start reconstruction. My Breast Surgeon suggested that I consider having a prophylactic mastectomy with reconstruction on the healthy breast as well. My Oncologist doesn't think it is necessary as i will always be in some kind of prophylactic treatment to (hopefully) prevent any recurrences. Unfortunately I am not a candidate for nipple sparing mastectomy on the healthy breast due to years of breastfeeding. The skin is way to thin and the nipple is southbound ;-) I am seriously stuck! Any thoughts? Dx 6/7/2009, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 17/19 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Newbie here AzKim cherneski

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2010 09:44AM dharmamama wrote: I am diabetic and decadron is NOT my friend. I discussed with my rad onc whether it is possible to receive WBR without decadron and his reply was "certainly". More studies are now suggesting that it may not be needed for the whole treatment, unless you are having symptoms of swelling. I used Boswellia after my craniotomy and I did not have any problems with swelling. Some NSAIDS may also be helpful. BTW the National Cancer Institute is conducting a study using Boswellian for swelling in people that have brain tumors. You can download a copy of the information from their website and show it to her doc.
Posts.Title: Is there a substitute for Decadron w/o the bad side affects? Joyce4123 K-Lo

Posts.Title: Just when I thought things were getting better... konakat Marple

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 11:02AM dharmamama wrote: Go Cyberknife! I was diagnosed 7/09 with stage 3c breast cancer and then diagnosed with a brain met in 5/10. I had a craniotomy and lesion removal because my doc wasn't convinced it was cancer given it's location. Well, it sure was. I too had Cyberknife afterwards as a "clean up".  Do to being diabetic, decadron just wasn't a good choice for me and my CyberKnife team at Stanford told me that decadron may not even be necessary. Apparently it is a bit controversial. I did use boswellia and am happy to report that I didn't have any swelling issues AND I just had my first clean brain MRI!
